ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to consider the world in categories, which is a different way of thinking that in past psych classes
I really liked thinking about psychology in a very new way. This was very different type of class that helped me develop my writing skills and thinking about a familiar subject in a new way
Knowledge about categorization. I also learned more about how to out researchers' arguments in conversation with each other and refer to them when making my own points.

You learn how to defend an argument sharply, critically, and calmly. I also learned a lot about AI and robots from this course oddly enough, but most importantly I walked away with a deeper understanding of how the world and our mind works. It's a constellation of topics and themes, but it works! You also get really good at writing 200 word max reading responses.
Things are much less clearly defined the closer you get to boundaries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: very interactive learning with lots of student discussion. every class we went through case studies to put the concepts we learned into practice, which was a great way of learning and much more engaging than just talking.

More lecturing within  class 
Although the discussions and presentations were great, they were sometimes felt a bit long. Would have loved to hear more from Prof. Keil himself

I think the only way it could be improved is to make each topic a little more clear on the syllabus. but other than that the whole class was a strength. the readings were at first hard to get through but it gets easier as you go along.

Discussion aspect of the course was great, as were the presentations. It would have been nice to have more formal presentations on final papers (where students could take turn presenting without being interrupted)
strengths: weekly "case studies" (read: group debates) but they get really fun and are low stakes

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, this was a super interesting course and I learned a lot.
Yes, if they are looking for a complex psych course that is focused on discussions and a bit more abstract than the average psych course

Yes! if you want a really compelling class take it! But I will say you do have to put in some work into understanding and really doing the readings and you have to put in a lot of editing work in your reading responses because they have to be 200 words which for me was always a challenge as the readings gave me lots to write about.
Yes, it's a good psychology senior seminar and the material was always engaging

I would take this course if you're okay with being flexible and learning in a new way. I haven't taken any other course like this at Yale. I would stick it out even if you think the first class isn't the best because the skills and knowledge I walked away with are so worth it!
